results.headline: The Keys to Success

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vitus

results.summary_short: “Vitus” places uncomfortable impulses in opposition, then dramatizes them in the most unchallenging way imaginable.

results.headline: Sexy Tableaus

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One to Another

results.summary_short: The notion that French cinema consists mainly of pretentious soft-core pornography is an ignorant cliché, but “One to Another” does little to disprove it.

results.headline: Free Will, Held Hostage for Years in a Zealous War on Drugs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Over the GW

results.summary_short: “Over the G W” follows a troubled brother and sister as they are committed to a New Jersey treatment center by their well-meaning parents.

results.headline: Pick Your Poison: Fists or Fireballs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Live Free or Die Hard

results.summary_short: In “Live Free or Die Hard,” Bruce Willis is ready to earn our love again by performing the same lovably violent, meathead tricks as before.

results.headline: Hip-Hop Gangsters on an Isle of Chaos

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghosts of Cite Soleil

results.summary_short: Asger Leth’s “Ghosts of Cité Soleil” offers a tour of a notorious, hellish slum in Port-au-Prince, the capital of Haiti.

results.headline: Open Wide and Say ‘Shame’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sicko

results.summary_short: Michael Moore has never before made a film that stated his bedrock ideological principles as clearly and accessibly as “Sicko.”

results.headline: Oh, Dolly! When Sheep Go Bad, Forget the Peace in the Valley

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Sheep

results.summary_short: “Black Sheep” is essentially a silly, grisly elaboration of a simple idea: What if sheep started feasting on human flesh and turning their victims into huge ovine zombies?

results.headline: One Day (and Dead Body) at a Time

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Kill Me

results.summary_short: With its shadows and gallows humor, “You Kill Me” goes about as dark as a comedy can go before turning into tragedy or self-parody.

results.headline: Niceness Counts in Ark-Building, Too

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Evan Almighty

results.summary_short: “Evan Almighty,” in which Steve Carell is commanded by God (Morgan Freeman) to build an ark, is a movie far less interesting than its premise.

results.headline: Climbing Out on a Limb and Then Crawling Back

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Broken English

results.summary_short: The low-key comedy “Broken English” is a textbook example of an Indiewood film: a Hollywood fantasy wrapped in plain brown paper.

results.headline: A Look at Loss and Reinvention
results.display_title: The Real Dirt on Farmer John

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Real Dirt on Farmer John

results.summary_short: “What do you do when nothing is left?” is the question that drives “The Real Dirt on Farmer John.”

results.headline: A Jumbled Real World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Longing

results.summary_short: “Longing” intrigues because it presents an outwardly decent man falling equally in love with two women but eschews simplistic judgments.

results.headline: An Unlucky Number

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 1408

results.summary_short: A Stephen King short story is adapted and brought to the screen in “1408,” more psychological thriller than outright horror.

results.headline: An Athlete Doing Battle With His Past

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of White Palms

results.summary_short: The term “sports film” doesn’t do justice to “White Palms,” a punishing, beautiful drama about a troubled 30-something Hungarian gymnast.

results.headline: Industrial China’s Ravaging of Nature, Made Disturbingly Sublime

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Manufactured Landscapes

results.summary_short: “Manufactured Landscapes” is an absorbing if unsettling documentary about the work of the Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky.

results.headline: Bollywood Goes to Europe and Finds Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jhoom Barabar Jhoom

results.summary_short: “Jhoom Barabar Jhoom” is a giddy romantic comedy with star power, wanderlust and a charming can-do, why-not-the-kitchen-sink spirit.

results.headline: Video Game Arrives in the Flesh (Lots of It)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of DOA: Dead or Alive

results.summary_short: There was a time when movies like “DOA: Dead or Alive” lurked sheepishly at schoolboy height on video store shelves, spines straining to accommodate the charms of their actresses.

results.headline: Hard to Find Good Help? Not in This Little Town

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fido

results.summary_short: In the ticklishly amusing satire “Fido,” the undead stagger along like stunned toddlers.

results.headline: Junior Sleuth Finds Her Way to the Screen, With Knee-Socks Pulled Up High

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nancy Drew

results.summary_short: In “Nancy Drew,” the titular girl sleuth is decked out with air quotes and the full complement of knowing pop-culture accessories.

results.headline: Four Countries, Five Bands, One Coast-to-Coast Party

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gypsy Caravan

results.summary_short: As a music document and as a labor of unabashed love, the nonfiction feature “Gypsy Caravan” could hardly be better; as a movie, it could stand some improvement.
